title:
Leveraging the Versatility of DNA Origami and Electrochemistry for New
  Sensing Modalities
abstract:
Electrochemical Biosensors are uniquely positioned to offer real-time in vivo
molecular sensing due to their robustness to both biofluids and contaminants
found in biofluids, and their adaptability for the detection of different
analytes by their use of oligonucleotides or proteins as binding moiety. DNA
Origami, the folding of a long DNA scaffold by hundreds of shorter
oligonucleotide staple strands, allows the construction of nanoscale molecular
objects of essentially arbitrary form, flexibility and functionality. We
describe work at the intersection of these two fields and
their-hopefully-bright future together.
